title: AB 1673
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections related to firearms, rocket launchers, and explosive devices. The definition of a "firearm" is expanded to include rocket launchers and similar devices containing explosive materials. The Penal Code includes sections specifying firearms regulations, excluding antique firearms in certain provisions. Additionally, the definition of a "firearm" in Sections 34005 and 34010 excludes destructive devices. The Penal Code specifies firearms regulations, including definitions of "firearm" in various sections. The definition varies depending on the context, such as excluding destructive devices in certain provisions and including unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to functional firearms. In Sections 17280 and 24680, "firearm" is defined as in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted to functional firearms. The terms "frame" and "receiver" refer to the part of a firearm that houses the hammer, bolt, or firing mechanism and can be further machined to be used as part of a functional weapon. Section 16520 of the Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel using explosion or combustion force. The term includes the frame or receiver in various sections of the code. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" and includes specific sections that expand the definition to include devices like rockets or launchers containing explosive material. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" and includes specific sections that expand the definition to include devices like rockets or launchers containing explosive material. Section 16750, Section 16840(b), Section 25400, Sections 25850 to 26025, Section 26030(a), (b), and (c), Sections 26035 to 26055, and other provisions exclude unloaded antique firearms from the definition of a firearm. Additionally, Sections 34005 and 34010 exclude destructive devices from the definition of a firearm. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" and includes specific sections that expand the definition to include devices like rockets or launchers containing explosive material. Sections 26500 to 29150 outline various aspects related to firearms, including definitions and exclusions. For example, Section 27510 pertains to a specific aspect, while Sections 29010 to 29150 include provisions regarding unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted into functional firearms. In Sections 17280 and 24680, "firearm" is defined as in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into functional firearms. The terms "frame" and "receiver" refer to the part of a firearm that houses the firing mechanism and can be identified as part of a functional weapon. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to clarify these definitions. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections related to firearms, rocket launchers, and explosive devices. The definition of a "firearm" is expanded to include devices designed for emergency signaling. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into functional firearms. The terms "frame" and "receiver" refer to the part of a firearm that houses the hammer, bolt, or firing mechanism and can be identified as part of a functional weapon. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to clarify these definitions. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes sections ranging from 26600 to 31830, covering various aspects related to firearms. Additionally, the definition of "firearm" extends to devices like rockets or launchers containing explosive materials in specific provisions. The Penal Code sections from 16750 to 29180 define the term "firearm" and exclude unloaded antique firearms in certain provisions. Additionally, in Sections 34005 and 34010, a firearm does not include a destructive device. Sections 26500 to 29150 of the Penal Code define the term "firearm" and include provisions regarding unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to functional weapons. In Sections 17280 and 24680, "firearm" is defined as in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted to functional weapons. "Frame" and "receiver" refer to parts of a firearm that house the hammer, bolt, or firing mechanism and can be further machined to be used in a functional weapon. Section 1.1 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of Senate Bill 894 and certain conditions being met by January 1, 2017. Section 1.2 of the bill incorporates amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code proposed by this bill and other related bills, with specific conditions for its enactment by January 1, 2017. Section 1.3 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code from multiple bills, with specific conditions for its enactment by January 1, 2017. No reimbursement required by this act under California Constitution due to potential costs incurred by local agencies or school districts related to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
